nexttext: At this point it is clear that an observer defining the time in agreement with $T_0(r,t)$, will define the transformation (\ref{eq:nontrivial}) trivially in agreement with $\zeta^t=\delta_g t$, after relabeling index since this observer will ignore the contributions coming from the St\"uckelberg fields $A^\alpha(x)$. On the other hand, an observer defining the time arbitrarily, will perceive the full effects of the St\"uckelberg fields $A^\alpha(x)$ and then such observer will define the gauge transformations for the function $T_0(r,t)$ in agreement with eq. (\ref{eq:nontrivial}). For a vacuum defined in terms  of the St\"uckelberg functions, as it is the case defined in eq. (\ref{eq:hmunu}), it is clear that there will not be invariance under the generators involving the St\"uckelberg fields $A^\alpha(x)$. Then these generators are the source of the degeneracy and their number correspond to the amount of broken generators and as a consequence to the number of Nambu Goldstone bosons of the theory. In the present case, where gravity is taken into account and in addition it enters through an extra-parameter $\epsilon$, the degeneracy of the vacuum is equivalent to a multiplicity of Vainshtein scales, all of them connected through the symmetry transformations given in eq. (\ref{eq:nontrivial}). We can extend the St\"uckelberg field's definition by the introduction of the $U(1)$ symmetry as follows \cite{K}
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E16.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="T_{0}(r,t)\backsim t+A^{t}(x),\;\;\;\;\;\;\;A^{r}(x)=0." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>T</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>∽</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mrow><msup><mi>A</mi><mi>t</mi></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="22.1pt">,</mo><mrow><mrow><msup><mi>A</mi><mi>r</mi></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
In such a case, the transformation defined in eq. (\ref{eq:nontrivial}), is extended to become

\begin{eqnarray}   \label{eq:nontrivial2}
\delta_g T_0(r,t)=-\zeta(Y) \approx \partial^t\Lambda(x)-\zeta^t-A^\alpha\partial_\alpha\zeta^t-\frac{1}{2}A^\alpha A^\beta\partial_\alpha\partial_\beta\zeta^t+...,\nonumber\\
\delta_g\phi=-\Lambda(x).
\end{eqnarray}

For the special case where the St\"uckelberg fields are reduced to the scalar case $\phi$, then the previous transformations are reduced to

\begin{eqnarray}   \label{eq:nontrivial21}
\delta_g T_0(r,t)=-\zeta(Y) \approx \partial^t\Lambda(x)-\zeta^t,\nonumber\\
\delta_g\phi=-\Lambda(x).
\end{eqnarray}

Then the definition of the time in agreement with the observers is reduced to the way how the scalar field $\phi$ is defined. The field $\phi$ in a complex plane transform in the form $U(1)$. Then for this special case, the different observers located at different scales, are connected through the $U(1)$ symmetry transformations of the broken generators.  
 
\section{Conclusions}

In this paper we have demonstrated that the presence of gravity introduces an additional degeneracy on the vacuum solutions in massive gravity. The case analyzed in this manuscript is just an extension of the results obtained in \cite{Higgs}. Here the gravitational effects are introduced perturbatively through the parameter $\epsilon$. This is equivalent to introduce the graviton mass $m_g$ as an arbitrary and small parameter. The analysis of this paper reveals that the role of the broken generators of the theory is to connect in space the observers located at different scales. Equivalently, we can say that there is a multiplicity of Vainshtein scales, all of them connected through the broken generators of the theory.\\\\
